title: Varicose Veins with Venous Ulcer
diagnosis_topic: Chronic venous insufficiency leading to ulceration
setup_script: A 54-year-old woman complains of a painful ulcer on the medial aspect of her left ankle. She has a history of long-standing varicose veins and occupations requiring prolonged standing. She notices swelling and heaviness in her legs by the end of the day.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 125/78 mmHg, HR 80 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.9 C.
Dilated tortuous varicosities on left leg, hyperpigmented skin, pitting edema, shallow ulcer with exudate at medial malleolus.
Reflux in great saphenous vein; deep venous system patent.
Compression stockings, leg elevation, wound care with debridement and moist dressings.
Indicated for symptomatic reflux after ulcer healing.
Stripping or phlebectomy may be options; perforator ligation if incompetent.
Start topical or systemic antibiotics based on culture if cellulitis develops.
Weight management, avoid prolonged standing, daily calf exercises.
Valve incompetence leads to venous hypertension and skin changes.
Regular follow-up; consider skin graft if not healing after 3 months.
High recurrence; lifelong compression therapy recommended.

critical_decision_points: Identification of chronic venous insufficiency signs
Appropriate use of duplex ultrasound to assess reflux
Initiation of compression therapy and wound care
Selection of endovenous or surgical treatment after ulcer healing
Patient education and prevention of recurrence
